text: ZIKV - prME DNA vaccine induces antigen - specific T cells in C57BL / 6 mice The ability of the ZIKV - prME plasmid vaccine to induce cellular immune responses was evaluated . Groups of four female C57BL / 6 mice were immunised with either the control plasmid backbone ( pVax1 ) or the ZIKV - prME plasmid vaccine three times at 2 week intervals through intramuscular ( i . m . ) injection followed by electroporation at the site of delivery ( Figure 2a ) . One week after the third injection bulk splenocytes harvested from each animal and evaluated in ELISpot assays for their ability to secrete interferon - γ ( IFN - γ ) after ex vivo exposure to peptide pools encompassing ZIKV - prME . The assay results show that splenocytes from ZIKV - prME immunised mice produced a cellular immune response after stimulation with multiple ZIKV - E peptide pools ( Figure 2b ) . The region ( s ) of ZIKV - Env , which elicited the strongest cellular response ( s ) were evaluated by ELISpot assay in a matrix format using 22 peptide pools consisting of 15 - mers ( overlapping by 9 amino acids ) spanning the entire ZIKV - prME protein . Several pools demonstrated elevated T cell responses , with peptide pool 15 exhibiting the highest number of spot - forming units ( SFU ) ( Figure 2c ) . This matrix mapping analysis revealed a dominant prME epitope , ' IRCIGVSNR DFVEGM ' ( aa167 - 181 ) . This peptide was confirmed to contain a H2 - Db restricted epitope through analysis utilising the Immune Epitope Database Analysis Resource tool ( http : / / tools . iedb . org ) , which [UNK] supports that in this haplotype the antigen is effectively processed .
